conclusion: Looking at the P-V diagram showing a thermodynamic cycle, I'll analyze the internal energy at states a and c for an ideal gas going through adiabatic and isochoric processes.
Path c → d: Adiabatic expansion (pressure decreases, volume increases)
Path d → a: Isochoric cooling (pressure decreases, volume constant)
Path a → b: Adiabatic compression (pressure increases, volume decreases)
Path b → c: Isochoric heating (pressure increases, volume constant)

For an ideal gas: Internal energy U depends only on temperature: U = (3/2)nRT for monatomic gases or U = (5/2)nRT for diatomic gases. For isochoric processes (constant volume), ΔU = Q (heat added equals change in internal energy). For adiabatic processes, Q = 0 (no heat transfer).
In the diagram, states a and c are at the same vertical lines as states b and d respectively, meaning: Volume at a = Volume at d, Volume at b = Volume at c.

premise: Since internal energy U is only dependent on temperature for an ideal gas (U ∝ T), and we notice that: State c has higher pressure than state a at their respective volumes. For an ideal gas, P ∝ T at constant volume (from PV = nRT).
conclusion: Since Pc > Pa (at their respective volumes) and considering the ideal gas law: For state c: Pc·Vc = nRTc, For state a: Pa·Va = nRTa. Since Vc < Va (state c is at a smaller volume) and Pc > Pa, this means Tc > Ta.

premise: Since internal energy U ∝ T for an ideal gas, and Tc > Ta.
conclusion: The internal energy at state c is greater than the internal energy at state a (Uc > Ua).
